STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 15, 2023
Jill Schreuder
CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN - GR
40 JEFFERSON AVE,
GRAND RAPIDS, MI, 49503-4304
Re: License #: CB410245705
Dear Jill Schreuder:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
December 15, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB410245705
Licensee Group Organization: Catholic Charities West Michigan
Licensee Designee: JILL CHRISTINE SCHREUDER
Chief Administrator: Jill Schreuder
Name of Agency: CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN -
GR
Agency Address: 40 JEFFERSON AVE
GRAND RAPIDS, MI 49503-4304
Agency Telephone #: 6164561443
Original Issuance Date: 03/15/2002
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Evaluate
Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION

Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 12/4/2023

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(3) The personnel record shall contain:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s
performance within a probationary period of not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes hir or
her current responsibilities. After the initial
evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
One of sixteen personnel files reviewed did not contain a written evaluation as
required.
CPA Rule 400.12214 Compliance with the child protection law
An agency shall comply with the child protection
law, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Five of thirteen new personnel files reviewed did not have documentation the
agency was in compliance with the child protection law.
CPA Rule 400.12306 Application request
(3) An agency shall provide the licensee an
application for renewal of the license and document
the action not less than 60 calendar days before the
expiration of the license.
2

One of six foster home files reviewed did not provide the licensee an application for
renewal at least 60 days prior to the expiration of the license.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the department
at least 15 calendar days before the expiration date
of the foster home license.
Two of six foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the licensing
recommendation was made to the department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule.
Two of four special investigations reviewed did not contain documentation the foster
parent was provided a copy of the report within 10 calendar days of completion as
required.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy must
include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including
a behavioral/mental health and trauma screening,
within 30 calendar days from the date the child
entered into out-of-home placement, regardless of
the date of the last physical examination.
(ii) A physical examination every 14 months.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have the initial medical
examination/periodic medical examination completed as required.
Foster parent information
CPA Rule 400.12417
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(a) Child’s name.
3

(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s
health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the
child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological
factors relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the
foster parent to provide a stable, safe and
healthy environment for the foster child and
the foster family, including information about
siblings who do not reside in the foster home
as provided in federal law.
(i) Name of the assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and
emergency medical care.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-j of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlined within the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from the removal of the
home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Four of eight foster care files reviewed, and one of four independent living files
reviewed (5 of 48 service plans) did not have the Initial Service Plan/Updated
Service Plan completed timely.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the
foster child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in
t he child’s placement at least once every month.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have monthly visitation with the
worker and child in the foster placement as required.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be
recorded within 30 calendar days after placement in
4

independent living and updated at least once every
90 calendar days.
(a) All the following personal information pertaining
to the youth:
(xii) A photograph updated on an annual basis.
One of four independent living files reviewed did not contain an updated photograph
as required.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The agreement
must be reviewed with the youth at least once every
90 calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
One of four independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation the
independent living contract was updated and provided to the youth quarterly as
required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/12/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/4/2023
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned
change of placement or no later than three business
days after an unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,
step-down from a residential or hospital setting,
return from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
Five of eight foster care files reviewed and one of four independent living files reviewed
did not have FTM’s completed as required.
5

FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
business days of the FTM.
Seven of eight foster care files reviewed, and four of four independent living files
reviewed contained FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or the DHS 1105 was not
uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/12/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/4/2023
1/19/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/16/2022
FOM 722-06H Contact with supervisor
The caseworker must meet with their supervisor at
least monthly for case consultation on every
assigned case. Monthly case consultation may be
conducted in person or by video conference.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed and one of four independent living files
reviewed did not have documented monthly supervision with staff as required.
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans
within 14 days of the end of the report period.
One of eight foster care files reviewed, and one of four independent living files
reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case service plan within 14 days
as required.
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan &
Service Agreement
6

When completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate, including those of
parent(s)/guardians(s), foster care worker,
supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged
14 and older and in the case of placement agency
foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
Seven of eight foster care files reviewed, and three of four independent living files
reviewed (23 of 48 service plans) did not contain all of the required signatures on the
parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/12/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/4/2023
1/19/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/16/2022
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider
• Youth adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a
temporary court ward.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to
each placement.
• All medical and health professionals to whom
the child is newly referred to and accepted for
treatment or services prior to or at the first
scheduled appointment while the foster care
case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not
required.
• Older youth/young adults.
7

Five of eight foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and required
signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/12/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/4/2023
1/19/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/16/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Foster home renewal letter needs to be uploaded.
• Licensing training verifications need to include date.
• Letter provided to foster parents regarding 45 days extension for special
evaluations need to be dated.
• DHS 1105’s should be uploaded under FTM (a few were uploaded under
placement).
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were 1 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. A special evaluation was initiated on 9/25/2023 regarding allegations a
licensed foster parent’s nonreported adult household member choked and shoved a
foster child. The licensed foster parent was found to be in violation of licensing rules
and agency policy. In addition, licensed foster parent now has a confirmed case
due to threatened harm. Revocation of the foster home license has been initiated
due to this incident as well as repeated violation of licensing rules.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
renewal inspection completed on 12/12/2022 with a corrective action plan
approved on 1/4/2023. During the review the agency had six violations. Four
citations were noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this
period under review the agency noted that overall compliance was impacted, in a
part, by increased staff turnover as well as a high number of
emergency/unplanned replacements.
8

Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting requirements during
this review period. The Chief Administrator stated the CAP has been, in part,
successful, however the agency has experienced increased staff turnover and a
high number of emergency/unplanned replacements during the past year. The CA
indicated the agency has implemented new initiatives to address areas of non-
compliance and allow for an extra layer of accountability. The agency conducts
monthly case audits to assist with compliance. Staff, including upper management,
review the Book of Business on a weekly basis. In addition, the agency has added
a Compliance Coordinator position to assist staff with scheduling and uploading.
The CA expressed confidence that several areas will improve over the next review
period.
Financial Overview
Financial records were reviewed and there were no concerns identified.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors and coworkers are available to assist as
needed. Staff did not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and adoption services. All files were stored
securely including CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
9

12/15/2023
